perturbation.original_text: 1.2  Distributor's relationship to Airspan is that of an independent contractor, and nothing in this Agreement shall constitute Distributor as the agent or employee of Airspan.  Distributor shall have no authority to accept any order or make any offer (except as herein stated), or execute any instrument or make any commitment on behalf of Airspan.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.2  Distributor's relationship to Airspan is that of an independent contractor, and nothing in this Agreement shall constitute Distributor as the agent or employee of Airspan. Distributor shall have the authority to accept any order or make any offer (except as herein stated), or execute any instrument or make any commitment on behalf of Airspan.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a contradiction by granting the Distributor authority that is explicitly denied in the original text. Under common law and agency principles, an independent contractor generally lacks the authority to bind the principal (Airspan) unless specifically granted. By stating the Distributor *does* have authority, the contract now contains conflicting terms regarding the Distributor's powers, creating uncertainty about the scope of their agency.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Agency Law, Independent Contractor vs. Employee classifications under state and federal labor laws

perturbation.original_text: 10.2  Trade secrets are confidential information that includes ideas, concepts, techniques, processes, inventions, knowledge, and know-how developed by Airspan which:  (1) derives independent economic value, actual or potential, from not being generally known to, and not being readily ascertainable by proper means by, other persons who can obtain economic value from its disclosure or use; and (2) is subject to the efforts of Airspan that are reasonable under the circumstances to maintain its secrecy.  (This "trade secret" language comes from the Uniform Trade Secrets Act.)
perturbation.changed_text: 10.2  Trade secrets are confidential information that includes ideas, concepts, techniques, processes, inventions, knowledge, and know-how developed by Airspan which:  (1) derives independent economic value, actual or potential, from not being generally known to, and not being readily ascertainable by proper means by, other persons who can obtain economic value from its disclosure or use; and (2) is not subject to any efforts by Airspan to maintain its secrecy. (This "trade secret" language comes from the Uniform Trade Secrets Act.)
perturbation.explanation: This change directly contradicts the established legal definition of a trade secret. A key element of trade secret protection is the effort made to maintain its secrecy. By stating that the information is *not* subject to such efforts, it fails to meet the legal standard for a trade secret. This creates ambiguity in enforcing the confidentiality provisions of the contract, as the information may not qualify for trade secret protection under the law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Uniform Trade Secrets Act (UTSA), state trade secret laws

perturbation.original_text: 14.2 Subject to Sections 14.3 and 14.4, Airspan warrants that the Equipment sold to Distributor under this Agreement shall, under normal use and service, be free from defects in materials and faulty workmanship, and that the Software licensed to Distributor under this Agreement shall conform in all material respects to Airspan's published specifications therefor. The warranty period for any item of Equipment and related Software shall be twelve (12) months from the date of delivery of such Equipment and related Software to Distributor as set forth in Paragraph 8.1 (hereinafter, this period of time shall be referred to as the "Initial Warranty Period.")
perturbation.changed_text: 14.2 Subject to Sections 14.3 and 14.4, Airspan warrants that the Equipment sold to Distributor under this Agreement shall, under normal use and service, be free from defects in materials and faulty workmanship, and that the Software licensed to Distributor under this Agreement shall conform in all material respects to Airspan's published specifications therefor. The warranty period for any item of Equipment and related Software shall be twelve (12) months from the date of delivery of such Equipment and related Software to Distributor as set forth in Paragraph 8.1 (hereinafter, this period of time shall not be referred to as the "Initial Warranty Period.")
perturbation.explanation: By stating the term does not apply, even though it is explicitly defined in the original text, the contract now contains conflicting terms regarding the warranty's timeline, creating uncertainty about the scope of their warranty and whether there is any at all.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Warranty law, contract law, sale of goods
